ReportSection.title: AGE-WELL's Project Scorecard and Reporting Framework
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Please complete the project scorecard provided. You should specifically respond to the reviewer feedback from the Core Research Program (CRP) Request for Proposals, identifying areas of strength and weakness of the project and identifying concrete goals, activities and deliverables (e.g. a plan, report/paper, market analysis, environmental scan) for the Catalyst year.

The purpose of this exercise is to ready project teams to “hit the ground running” in 2020 and to strengthen each project across the five NCE program criteria (see definitions below).

As previously communicated, the expectations of the CRP Catalyst phase include activities related to:

  • Building partnerships and team capacity;
  • Developing knowledge mobilization and commercialization plans;
  • Developing relationships with the stakeholders (i.e., older adults and caregivers should be involved in all aspects of the project from the start);
  • Developing relationships and collaborations with the other projects within the Challenge Areas and across the Network; and
  • Recruitment of the full research team prior to April 2020.

As part of the initial planning and ongoing work during the Catalyst phase, Project Leads should consider connecting with their research team, partners and stakeholders (e.g. older adults, caregivers, service providers, government agencies) to reflect on how to best to address:

  • Transdisciplinary approach to research and team-working;
  • Stakeholder involvement in all aspects of the project, including decision-making;
  • Involvement of end-users in co-production methods;
  • Integrated knowledge mobilization (e.g. commercialization, policy development, communications);
  • Ethical considerations; and
  • Equity, diversity and inclusion.

Through these activities, projects should be positioned not only to maximize the likelihood of producing specific outputs, but also to contribute to the development of AGE-WELL Challenge Areas (https://agewell-nce.ca/aw2020).

Note that you are also asked to indicate any supports from which you feel your project would benefit. AGE-WELL’s Network Management Office is keen to work with all the CRP Catalyst projects and has access to numerous resources across the Network that may be useful to projects. For example, support through our Crosscutting Activities: Knowledge Mobilization, Commercialization, Transdisciplinary Working, Training and Mentorship.

Key Dates: The project scorecard should be submitted to AGE-WELL by July 4, 2019. It will be used by the Network Management Office to create individual project support and resource packages (e.g. links to specific partners, cross-cutting activities, people, etc.). In January 2020, projects will return to the scorecard and reflect on their work during the Catalyst phase. The updated scorecard and a two-page progress report will be submitted for evaluation.

NCE Program Criteria

Scientific Excellence
The AGE-WELL Core Research Program (CRP) must be driven to address Canadian needs and problems and to demonstrate world-class scientific achievements. AGE-WELL is also committed to a transdisciplinary approach.

Networking and Partnerships
The project must demonstrate that it has brought together the key individuals and organizations needed to generate and implement multifaceted solutions to the complex challenges it is designed to address. It must be built on relationships with partners and the receptor community that will accelerate the activities, outcomes and impact of the project.

Knowledge and Technology Exchange and Exploitation – Knowledge Mobilization & Commercialization
NCE Networks are expected to generate social and economic benefits by ensuring the rapid flow of knowledge, ideas and innovations from researchers to Canadian receptors. Projects are expected to demonstrate that the appropriate activities will be undertaken and the appropriate resources allocated to maximize those benefits through effective stakeholder engagement and communication.

Training of HQP
Training is expected to add value to the formal training initiatives already available through the academic community and should aim at helping HQP find employment in the Canadian economy, particularly in sectors related to technology and aging. HQP should be directly involved in the range of activities in a multi-disciplinary team research project and should work closely with industry and community partners and be involved in collaborating within the AGE-WELL research network and partner universities.

Project and Management and Team
Projects need to have effective management and team-working processes in place and to demonstrate that the team possesses the necessary expertise and capacity to successfully complete their project
